0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0ZV2OA	Clinton leads Trump by 12 points ahead of Republican convention: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Grant Smith and Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump trailed Democratic rival Hillary Clinton by 12 percentage points in a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday
column2: making him the clear underdog ahead of next week's Republican National Convention.Forty-five percent of likely voters supported former Secretary of State Clinton
column3: 33 percent supported Trump
column4: the wealthy businessman
column5: and the remainder supported neither
column6: according to the July 11-15 online poll.The survey showed little change from Tuesday
column7: when Clinton had led Trump by 13 percentage points.Clinton has been ahead in the poll since early January. Trump only approached her level of support in May
column8: after his last two remaining rivals quit the race and he became the presumptive Republican nominee.Trump's favorability has dropped since then
column9: as his campaign began to focus on the Nov. 8 general election.

column1: Trump has faced criticism in recent weeks over his now-defunct Trump University venture
column2: which is accused of making false promises
column3: and over his anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim rhetoric.The poll results were mostly gathered before Thursday night's deadly truck attack in Nice
column4: France
column5: and before Trump's announcement on Friday that Indiana Governor Mike Pence would be his vice presidential running mate.The poll results suggest that Clinton's use of personal email for government business while secretary of state and her handling of classified information have not damaged her support among likely voters.

column1: But other polls show a closer race. The CBS News/NY Times telephone poll has the candidates tied at 40 percent each
column2: while a McClatchy/Marist telephone poll has Clinton leading by just 3 percentage points
column3: 42 percent to Trump's 39 percent.

column1: Trump may get a bump in the polls following next week's convention in Cleveland
column2: where the party is expected to rally behind him as the nominee. In 2012
column3: support for Republican nominee Mitt Romney rose about 5 percentage points following the convention that year. The Democratic convention is set for the following week
column4: opening July 25 in Philadelphia.The Reuters/Ipsos poll surveyed 1
column5: 186 likely voters across the continental United States
column6: Alaska and Hawaii. It has a credibility interval
column8: of 3 percentage points. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-saudi-usa-congress-idUSKCN0ZV1W0	Pages of U.S. 9/11 report detailing possible Saudi ties made public	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The U.S. Congress on Friday released a long-classified section of the official report on the Sept. 11 attacks describing an array of potential links between some of the hijackers and officials in Saudi Arabia.The 28 pages of the report on the 2002 investigation focus on potential Saudi government ties to the 2001 aircraft attacks on the United States
column2: in which nearly 3
column3: 000 people died.The report said the alleged links had not been independently verified.The pages were released by the House of Representatives Intelligence Committee after years of wrangling in Washington between Congress and different administrations
column4: Republicans and Democrats
column5: and urging by families of those killed.""The matter is now finished
column6: Saudi Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir told a news conference in Washington. Asked whether the report exonerated the kingdom
column7: he replied: ""Absolutely.""The release of the previously classified pages is unlikely to end the controversy over the role of Saudi Arabia
column8: an important U.S. partner in the Middle East. Many U.S. officials who opposed their release had worried they would damage diplomatic relations.Fifteen of the 19 Sept. 11 hijackers were Saudi citizens.""According to various FBI documents and CIA memorandum
column11: apparently had contacts with individuals who may be connected to the Saudi Government
column13: giving a catalog of alleged links.

column1: They included reported contacts between Saudis in California
column2: money possibly sent from the Saudi royal family to the hijackers and even a statement that a reported Saudi Interior Ministry official stayed at the same Virginia hotel as one hijacker in September 2001.One section said Omar al-Bayoumi
column3: said to be a Saudi intelligence officer
column4: met with two hijackers at a public place after they arrived in San Diego. Citing Federal Bureau of Investigation files
column5: it said his salary rose to $3
column6: 700 a month from $465 two months after two of the hijackers arrived in California.Another described how two of the hijackers asked flight attendants technical questions during a trip in 1999 from Phoenix to Washington to attend a party at the Saudi embassy. One tried twice to enter the cockpit. The plane made an emergency landing and the FBI investigated
column7: but did not prosecute.The newly declassified pages also say a telephone number found in a telephone book of Abu Zubaydah
column8: a Saudi-born al Qaeda operative captured in Pakistan
column9: was for a Colorado corporation that managed the affairs of the residence of Prince Bandar bin Sultan
column10: the former Saudi ambassador to Washington.

column1: LAWSUITS AHEAD?

The Office of the Director of National Intelligence said its agreement to the release is not an indication that the intelligence community agrees with the pages' accuracy or concurs with the information it contains.The office also on Friday released a declassified summary of an assessment of whether Riyadh may have supported al Qaeda before and after the attacks
column2: saying the Saudi government and many of its agencies had been infiltrated and exploited by individuals associated with or sympathetic to Osama bin Laden's militant network.Several members of Congress said they were pleased the pages had finally been released. Representative Adam Schiff
column3: the top Democrat on the intelligence panel
column4: said he hoped the release would quiet rumors.

column1: The Intelligence Community and the 9/11 Commission
column2: which followed the Joint Inquiry that produced these so-called 28 pages
column3: investigated the questions they raised and was never able to find sufficient evidence to support them
column4: he said.Legislation that would allow families of Sept. 11 victims to sue Saudi Arabia
column5: was passed unanimously by the U.S. Senate and is making its way through the House
column6: despite President Barack Obama's veto threat.""While the pages do not reach a conclusion regarding Saudi involvement in the 9/11 attacks
column7: they provide more than enough evidence to raise serious concerns
column8: said Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut. His state was home to many people killed when planes hit the World Trade Center in neighboring New York.Sept. 11 families made clear the pages' release would not stop their push for the legislation. ""Congress has to stand up for the interests of the thousands of innocent Americans who lost loved ones on 9/11
column9: one group said in a statement.White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters before the pages were released that they would show no evidence of Saudi complicity.The Obama administration sent a declassified version of the 28 pages
column10: with many lines and sentences blacked out to protect intelligence sources and methods
column11: to Congress on Friday morning. The House intelligence panel released it a few hours later. (Additional reporting by Yara Bayoumy
column14: Amanda Becker; Editing by James Dalgleish and Tom Brown)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-saudi-usa-reaction-idUSKCN0ZV2BI	Saudi says hopes release of '28 pages' clears up 9/11 suspicions	"
WASHINGTON Saudi Arabia welcomed on Friday the release of classified pages of the official report on the Sept. 11 attacks
column2: and hoped their release would clear up suspicions about Riyadh's actions
column3: intentions or long-term friendship with the United States.""Since 2002
column4: the 9/11 Commission and several government agencies
column5: including the CIA and the FBI
column6: have investigated the contents of the '28 Pages' and have confirmed that neither the Saudi government
column8: nor any person acting on behalf of the Saudi government provided any support or encouragement for these attacks
column9: Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States

column1: We hope the release of these pages will clear up
column2: once and for all
column3: any lingering questions or suspicions about Saudi Arabia's actions
column4: intentions
column5: or long-term friendship with the United States.""

3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-pence-gays-idUSKCN0ZV2SW	Trump's VP pick rankles Republican gay rights activists	"
By Ginger Gibson and Emily Stephenson
| CLEVELAND/WASHINGTON

CLEVELAND/WASHINGTON Donald Trump's choice of Mike Pence as his vice presidential running mate has irked some Republican activists who see the Indiana governor's years of opposition to gay rights initiatives as a setback to efforts to broaden the party's appeal.The pick could bolster Trump's support among religious conservatives
column2: but it also opens up a new line of attack for Democrats and liberals seeking to paint the New York businessman as a divisive candidate
column3: putting at risk his efforts to woo moderate voters ahead of the Nov. 8 election against Democrat Hillary Clinton.[nL1N1A10HR]Rachel Hoff
column4: the first openly gay member of the Republican Party's platform committee
column5: has spent time in Cleveland ahead of next week's party convention trying repeatedly to get the party to change its official position on gay marriage and adoption by gay couples. She was dismayed by the choice of Pence.""After the Pence announcement
column6: I think the question is - is Trump really moderate on gay rights issues? It seems more likely his rhetoric has been a smoke screen
column7: Hoff said. ""There's no substance behind it. By picking Pence
column8: Trump is signaling his administration may not be any friendlier to the LGBT (lesbian
column11: a Republican strategist in Indiana who has pushed for the party to be more open to gay members
column12: was similarly disappointed.""Picking Pence shows that he maybe doesn't care about that community as much as he tried to profess that he did
column13: she said of Trump.Clinton's campaign seized on the announcement to attack Pence's record on gay rights issues
column14: saying it ""embarrassed"" the people of Indiana. Clinton has previously called Trump the most divisive candidate ""in our lifetimes
column15: referring to his calls to temporarily ban Muslims from entering the country and to deport millions of undocumented immigrants.In 2015
column16: Pence found himself at the center of a national uproar when he signed a bill that he said was meant to protect religious liberty
column17: but which critics countered would allow business owners to deny services to gay people.

column1: After intense pressure from liberal groups and large corporations
column2: he asked lawmakers to clarify that businesses could not deny services on the basis of sexual orientation
column3: calling it a ""subject of great misunderstanding.""He has also fought against same-sex marriage and allowing gay people to serve openly in the military. A U.S. Supreme Court ruing last year legalized gay marriage nationwide and the Pentagon in 2011 ended the ban on openly gay and lesbian people serving in the military.In 2009
column4: while a member of the U.S. Congress
column5: Pence argued against expanding the definition of a hate crime to include sexual orientation
column6: calling it an attempt to ""advance a radical social agenda."" The federal hate crimes law was expanded to make this inclusion.DIVIDED PARTY

column1: Gay supporters of Trump are hopeful Pence will have little influence on a potential Trump administration. Trump has declared himself the most gay-friendly candidate in the election. He expressed support for the gay community after a mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando in June that killed 49 people
column2: and broke from his party during an argument  about transgender bathroom usage
column3: saying people could use the bathroom of their choosing at his office building Trump Tower in New York.That has cheered moderate Republicans who have been seeking to appeal to younger
column4: more liberal voters.""Donald Trump is the nominee of the party and Donald Trump is going to set policy
column5: said Chris Barron
column6: who has launched LGBTrump
column7: a group seeking to encourage gays to vote for Trump.

column1: Pence
column3: comes from a different wing of the divided Republican Party than Trump
column4: one that is dominated by evangelicals in southern and midwestern states. Conservatives were elated with his selection.""It's the best conservatives could possibly want
column5: said Brent Bozell
column6: a conservative leader. The pro-gay rights group Log Cabin Republicans said it would seek to pressure the Republican Party at the Cleveland national convention to adopt a more gay-friendly policy platform
column7: including by running a full-page ad in a local paper.The party's platform committee met early in the week to draft official policy positions on myriad issues. The document
column8: which carries little significance beyond the symbolic
column9: calls for a constitutional amendment to reverse the Supreme Court's decision legalizing gay marriage and included a veiled acceptance of gay conversion therapy
column10: a practice that has widely been criticized as harmful to children.Despite the disappointment that gay rights activists are feeling
column11: Log Cabin Republican president Gregory Angelo said he thinks voters are going to look at Trump's past statement on gay rights and not where Pence stands. Trump has spent little time talking about social issues and has instead focused on immigration and economic issues. ""Donald Trump rose to stardom as our presumptive nominee because he showcased an opposition to illegal immigration and unfair trade deals. That's what's resonating with the Republican electorate this year
column12: he said. (Reporting by Ginger Gibson and Emily Stephenson; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Frances Kerry)"

column1: The 28 pages of the report on the 2002 investigation focus on potential Saudi links to the 2001 aircraft attacks on the United States

5	http://reuters.com/article/us-trade-ttip-idUSKCN0ZV25O	EU and U.S. seek trade deal this year
column2: knowing large hurdles remain	"

column1: By Philip Blenkinsop
| BRUSSELS
BRUSSELS EU and U.S. negotiators said on Friday that they still needed to overcome large differences for a transatlantic free trade deal to be sealed this year
column2: and factor in the impending exit from the European Union of Britain
column3: one of the United States' biggest export markets.The two sides are trying to agree on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)
column4: which supporters say could boost each economy by some $100 billion at a time when growth in China and emerging markets is slowing.Chief EU negotiator Ignacio Garcia Bercero and U.S. counterpart Dan Mullaney told a news conference after a 14th round of talks that both sides were committed to sealing a deal before U.S. President Barack Obama leaves office at the turn of the year.The partners have made progress on tariff elimination and on regulatory cooperation.However
column5: they are stuck over EU demands including greater access to public sector tenders; Garcia Bercero described the U.S. offer as a serious cause of concern.Likewise
column6: Washington is unhappy with the EU offer on services.

column1: Given the importance of this sector to both of our economies ... progress here has been noticeably and painfully slow
column2: said Mullaney.He also said that
column3: while the economic rationale for TTIP remained strong
column4: Britain's exit from the European Union would force a rethink as it was the largest market anywhere for U.S. services
column5: and took 25 percent of U.S. exports to the EU.""Imagine if the United States said
column6: for instance
column8: maybe TTIP will not apply to California'. There is a certain reflection that the parties need to have on those kind of developments.""

column1: The two sides had previously planned to produce a single consolidated TTIP text by the end of July. Garcia Bercero said that was now more likely to come by the end of September after further meetings between U.S. trade chief Michael Froman and EU commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom.Garcia Bercero acknowledged that the political environment was becoming more challenging. The environmental group Greenpeace echoed the view of many anti-TTIP campaigners on Friday by saying that it was time to hit the 'Stop' button.But the EU negotiator said TTIP was instead a positive response to concerns about globalization.
If we want to have a shot at shaping globalization
column2: we need a like-minded partner that shares largely our views
column3: he said.Mullaney talked of a ""unique window of opportunity"" to complete TTIP this year that should not be allowed to slip away.""After this year
column4: with one political transition after another over the next few years
column5: it could be quite a while before we pick up negotiations again."" (Reporting By Philip Blenkinsop; Editing by Kevin Liffey)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-vicepresident-idUSKCN0ZT1RV	White House hopeful Trump nears end of vice presidential search	"
By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican Donald Trump neared the end of his vice presidential search on Thursday and appeared to be leaning toward Indiana Governor Mike Pence
column2: a conservative with the potential to unify divided Republicans.The presumptive Republican presidential nominee tweeted on Wednesday night that he would announce his choice on Friday at 11 a.m. (1500 GMT) in Manhattan.The New York businessman is to be formally nominated as the party's candidate for the Nov. 8 election at the Republican National Convention next week in Cleveland. Traditionally
column3: the vice presidential choice is used to build enthusiasm among party loyalists.Trump's choice of running mate is seen as critical because his defeat of 16 rivals in the Republican primary race left the party divided and some party leaders are still uneasy about some of his campaign positions
column4: and his style.Sources familiar with campaign operations cautioned that while Pence and former House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich were finalists
column5: Trump could always have a last-minute change of heart and choose someone else from his short list.

column1: A source close to the campaign said Trump appeared to be  leaning toward Pence but could easily change his mind.Gingrich told an ABC News correspondent he expected to hear Trump's decision after 1 p.m. EDT and would not be surprised if Trump chooses Pence. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column3: a former rival to Trump in the presidential race
column4: is also high on the list of potential running mates and provides the kind of counterpunch to Democratic rival Hillary Clinton that Republicans like.

column1: Pence
column3: a former congressman
column4: is seen as a safe choice
column5: not too flashy but popular among conservatives
column6: with Midwestern appeal and the ability to rally more party faithful behind Trump.Gingrich
column8: is a close adviser to Trump with a wealth of ideas and deep experience in the legislative process from his time as speaker of the House of Representatives in the 1990s.In what has been an unusually public process
column11: sat down with both Pence and Gingrich separately in Indianapolis on Wednesday.

column1: He also met with a fourth potential No. 2
column2: U.S. Senator Jeff Sessions
column4: of Alabama
column5: who has been one of Trump's closest advisers.The New York businessman had dinner with Pence on Tuesday night after they appeared together at a rally. Trump
column6: joined by daughter Ivanka and sons Donald Jr. and Eric Trump
column7: had breakfast with Pence and his wife
column9: on Wednesday at the governor's residence in Indianapolis.Trump adviser Ed Brookover told CNN that Trump ""first and foremost"" wants a running mate who he has good chemistry with and someone who can help him govern best. (Reporting By Steve Holland; Editing by Peter Cooney and Frances Kerry)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-muslims-idUSKCN0ZV20C	Republicans
column2: Democrats sharply divided over Muslims in America: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"

column1: By Emily Flitter and Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Many Americans view Islam unfavorably
column2: and supporters of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump are more than twice as likely to view the religion negatively as those backing Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column3: according to a Reuters/Ipsos online poll of more than 7
column4: 000 Americans.It shows that 37 percent of American adults have a ""somewhat unfavorable"" or ""very unfavorable"" view of Islam. This includes 58 percent of Trump supporters and 24 percent of Clinton supporters
column5: a contrast largely mirrored by the breakdown between Republicans and Democrats.By comparison
column6: respondents overall had an equally unfavorable view of atheism at 38 percent
column8: 16 percent for Judaism and 8 percent for Christianity. Spokespeople for Trump and Clinton declined to comment.The poll took place before an attacker on Thursday drove his truck into a holiday crowd in Nice
column10: killing more than 80 people in what President Francois Hollande called a terrorist act. Police sources said the driver
column12: was not on a watch list of intelligence services and no Islamist militant group immediately claimed responsibility for the attack.The race for the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election has put a spotlight on Americans' views of Muslims with Trump proposing a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States. He repeated the proposal after Omar Mateen
column13: a New York-born Muslim armed with an assault rifle
column14: killed 49 people in an attack on a Florida gay nightclub last month. The ideological divide between Trump and Clinton supporters is set against a backdrop of increasing violence and discrimination against Muslims in the United States.

column1: The poll shows 78 percent of Trump supporters and 36 percent of Clinton supporters said that when compared to other religions
column2: Islam was more likely to encourage acts of terrorism. Trump supporters were also about twice as likely as Clinton supporters to say that Islam was more encouraging of violence toward Americans
column3: women and gay people. Polling on none of the other belief systems and their perceived connection to terrorism or violence came close to matching those numbers.Clinton has called for a more inclusive environment within American society and for a joint effort between the U.S. government and Muslim countries to battle the spread of Islamist militancy. She has criticized Trump's harsh statements about Muslims and Mexicans while Trump has bemoaned what he calls American society's devotion to political correctness.

column1: Graphic: tmsnrt.rs/29IPJ6lTRUMP
column2: REPUBLICANS ALIGNED

column1: Party affiliation accounted for the deepest division among Americans where their views on Muslims were concerned. Respondents' status as rich or poor
column2: young or old
column3: or male or female did not offer as pronounced an overall view as did their identification as Democrats or Republicans.

column1: If it was true that Trump did not represent Republicans broadly defined
column2: you would think Republicans would look different; they don't
column3: said Douglas McAdam
column4: a sociology professor at Stanford University who studies American politics.""It goes against the claims of the (former presidential candidate) Mitt Romneys of the world
column5: that Trump is not really a Republican
column6: that he doesn't represent the Republican party. He seems to be resonating with Republicans generally.""According to the Council on American-Islamic Relations
column8: attacks on American Muslims and on mosques in the United States rose in 2015 to their highest level ever recorded. The group said 31 incidents of damage or destruction of mosques were reported; there were 11 incidents in which a Muslim person was the target of a slur or another kind of harassment. The Reuters/Ipsos poll ran in all 50 states from June 14 to July 6. It included 7
column9: 473 American adults and has a credibility interval
column11: of 1 percentage point. (Reporting By Emily Flitter; Editing by Paul Thomasch and Howard Goller)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ryan-idUSKCN0ZV228	House Speaker Ryan on Pence: 'No better choice'	"
WASHINGTON U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan welcomed Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's choice of Mike Pence as a running mate on Friday
column2: saying the Indiana governor comes from ""the heart of the conservative movement.""""I can think of no better choice for our vice-presidential candidate. We need someone who is steady and secure in his principles
column3: someone who can cut through the noise and make a compelling case for conservatism. Mike Pence is that man
column4: Ryan said in a statement.

column1: (Reporting by Doina Chiacu; Editing by David Alexander)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-pence-climatechange-idUSKCN0ZU2OB	Trump's expected VP pick: coal advocate who defied Obama's climate agenda	"
By Valerie Volcovici and Grant Smith
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK
WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Republican Donald Trump's selection of Indiana Governor Mike Pence as his running mate cheered the U.S. energy industry and dismayed green advocates
column2: with both sides citing Pence's support for coal mining and defiance of President Barack Obama's climate-change agenda.Trump
column3: the presumptive Republican presidential nominee
column4: has called climate change a hoax and promised to gut U.S. environmental regulations in order to help the ailing oil and coal sectors. A Trump-Pence ticket will quash any expectation that the New York businessman might soften that stance heading into the Nov. 8 election.""Governor Pence has been a vocal opponent of the administration's Clean Power Plan
column5: said Laura Sheehan
column6: spokeswoman for the Washington-based lobby group American Council on Clean Coal Electricity.  ""We would hope to see a continuation
column7: she said.Trump announced Pence as his running mate in a Twitter post on Friday morning
column8: ending days of speculation over the choice ahead of the party's national convention in Cleveland next week. [nL1N1A10HR]Pence
column10: is listed on Obama's ""call out the climate change deniers"" website for arguing that the science behind climate change has not yet been resolved.In June 2015
column11: Pence wrote to Obama saying that Indiana
column13: would not comply with the Clean Power Plan regulating power plant emissions
column14: calling it ""ill-advised."" Indiana is one of more than 25 states that have challenged the centerpiece of the Democratic president's environmental agenda.

column2: Pence alarmed local environmental groups by overturning an energy efficiency program enacted by his Republican predecessor
column3: Mitch Daniels
column4: saying it was too expensive for the state's manufacturers. The Indiana Public Utility Commission had estimated the program would create more than 18
column5: 600 jobs.""The choice of Pence shows Trump has little interest in appealing to anyone outside of his extremist base and Big Polluters
column6: said Clay Schroers
column7: a director at the League of Conservation Voters environmental group.

column1: SUPPORT FOR TRADITIONAL ENERGY

Trump has long signaled his support of traditional energy production - part of his broader appeal to blue-collar American voters. He outlined plans in May to sweep away environmental regulations ushered in by Obama
column2: scrap the Paris Climate Accord
column3: and revive the Keystone XL pipeline proposal - moves that would reverse years of gains by the green movement.Trump's Democratic rival
column4: Hillary Clinton
column5: in contrast
column6: has promised more stringent regulation of the energy sector
column7: efforts to boost renewable fuels use
column8: and a commitment to join other nations to combat global climate change.

column1: Pence ran for governor in 2012 after serving in the U.S. Congress. His campaign for governor received more than $850
column2: 000 from the energy sector
column3: about 3 percent of the total
column4: according to campaign finance disclosures.More than $300
column5: 000 of that came from the billionaire Koch brothers
column6: strong advocates of small government and fiscal conservatism who took a liking to Pence.Both David and Charles Koch have said they will not support the Trump ticket. Trump has alarmed many Republican establishment figures with his fiery rhetoric on immigration and trade. But a former high-ranking operative in the Koch political organization who is close to both brothers said Pence could help make the donor network more receptive to Trump's campaign. (Writing by Richard Valdmanis; Editing by Frances Kerry and Jonathan Oatis)"
